Award.AwardTitle: Valence Subband Engineering in High Al-content AlGaN Quantum Wells Active Regions for Deep Ultraviolet Lasers and Emitters

Division.LongName: Div Of Electrical, Commun & Cyber Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
The objective of this research is to conduct comprehensive studies on the issues and solutions to achieve high performance III-Nitride deep ultraviolet (UV) light-emitting diodes (LEDs) and lasers emitting in the 240-300 nm regime. The research will lead to electrically-injected deep UV emitters applicable for homeland security, water purification, environmental sensing, and biochemical agent detection. The program allows graduate and undergraduate students to be trained in multidisciplinary research, encompassing the physics of semiconductor optoelectronics materials and devices, material physics and epitaxy, semiconductor nanostructures, and device design and fabrications. The program will enable the training for two PhD students in III-Nitride technologies, which is critical for both deep UV emitters and solid state lighting applications.


The approach pursued in this program is to exploit a new method by introducing a nanoscale layer to achieve valence subband arrangement in the active regions, which will result in improved optical gain and spontaneous emission rate, as well as the ability to control the polarization of the emission in the mid and deep UV spectral regimes. The material development and epitaxy of novel AlGaN-based and AlInN-based quantum wells with large optical gain, specifically for achieving high performance deep UV LEDs and lasers, will be pursued. The implementation of these novel quantum wells in device structures will be pursued for achieving high-performance electrically-injected III-Nitride deep UV emitters.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The NSF program focuses on the pursuit of nanoscale AlGaN and AlInN semiconductor technology for deep ultraviolet (UV) lasers and light-emitting diodes (LEDs). The pursuit of high Al-content AlGaN is required for enabling emission in the deep UV spectral regime, however, the performances of these devices are limited by the low material quality and the unfavorable band structures, which result in low-efficiency devices especially with transverse-electric polarization emission. The use of GaN-based delta layer (in nanoscale) integrated within the AlGaN and AlInN allows the rearrangement of the band structures with favorable valence subband configuration, which enables the control of the polarization emission, increase the efficiency, and reduce the laser threshold in deep UV emitters. The applications of the deep UV emitters include water purification, non-line-of-sight communications, and biochemical detections in environments.

The tasks covered in the project include material synthesis, computational material sciences, device physics, and device characterizations of AlGaN and AlInN based technologies. The material synthesis was carried out by using metalorganic chemical vapor deposition, and some of the key results include high-quality and low defect density AlInN material system. The integration of AlGaN and AlInN as direct-barrier layer in InGaN-based active region was also performed, as this demonstrated the ability for the barrier / QW interface for controlling the light emission from the QW. This program also results in a new invention of "digital alloy", which opens up the ability for synthesizing ternary or quarternary material from the layering of binary 2D layers. The digital alloy also results in new and superior electronics and optical properties over the conventional random alloy materials.

The program also enables the support of three doctoral students in the areas of wide bandgap semiconductors. All three students have completed their doctoral studies, and they are presently contributing to the scientific community as a university professor and engineer/scientist in industry. The scientific impacts enabled from the work will be of great relevance for advancing the sensors, emitters, and integration technologies based on GaN / AlGaN / AlInN semiconductors for water purifications and environmental applications.
